0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• routine primary poliovirus immunization of adults in the United States is not recommended
  • Poliomyelitis, acute; Prophylaxis: unvaccinated and increased risk for exposure: 0.5 mL IM or SUBQ x 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2 months, and 6 to 12 months
  • Poliomyelitis, acute; Prophylaxis: unvaccinated and 2 to less than 3 months available before protection is needed: 0.5 mL IM or SUBQ x 3 doses at least 1 month apart
  • Poliomyelitis, acute; Prophylaxis: unvaccinated and 1 to 2 months available before protection is needed: 0.5 mL IM or SUBQ x 2 doses at least 1 month apart
  • Poliomyelitis, acute; Prophylaxis: unvaccinated and less than 1 month available before protection is needed: 0.5 mL IM or SUBQ single dose
  • Poliomyelitis, acute; Prophylaxis: incompletely vaccinated with oral or injectable vaccine and increased risk for exposure: 0.5 mL IM or SUBQ x 1 dose; complete a primary series if time permits
  • Poliomyelitis, acute; Prophylaxis: completely vaccinated and increased risk of exposure: 0.5 mL IM or SUBQ single dose

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Poliomyelitis, acute; Prophylaxis: unvaccinated: 0.5 mL IM or SUBQ x 4 doses at age 2, 4, 6 to 18 months, and booster at age 4 to 6 years; minimum age to start series is 6 weeks; do not give the first 3 doses more frequently than 4 weeks apart; give the fourth dose at least 6 months after the third dose
  • Poliomyelitis, acute; Prophylaxis: incompletely vaccinated: 0.5 mL IM or SUBQ x 1 to 3 doses to complete a 4-dose series regardless of age and when both oral and injectable vaccine were administered as part of a series; dose 4 is not required if dose 3 is administered at age 4 years or older and at least 6 months after previous dose
  • Poliomyelitis, acute; Prophylaxis: completely vaccinated before age 4 years: 0.5 mL IM or SUBQ x 1 dose as additional dose at age 4 to 6 years and at least 6 months after previous dose

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• acute febrile illness; defer vaccination until after recovery (manufacturer); acute illness with or without fever, moderate or severe; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction (CDC)
  • anaphylaxis or anaphylactic shock occurring within 24 hours of administration of one dose of vaccine; no further doses should be given
  • hypersensitivity to any component of the vaccine, including 2-phenoxyethanol, formaldehyde, streptomycin, neomycin, and polymixin B

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• allergic reactions to neomycin, streptomycin, polymixin B, 2-phenoxyethanol and formaldehyde (used in the production of this vaccine) may occur
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome has been reported
  • immunodeficient patients or patients under immunosuppressive therapy may not develop a protective immune response against paralytic poliomyelitis after administration
  • pregnancy; can be administered if there is a risk for exposure to wild-type poliovirus infection

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Inactivated poliovirus vaccine is a highly purified trivalent vaccine that stimulates production of neutralizing antibodies against poliovirus type 1, 2 and 3 and stimulates antibody responses in most children.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    • may be administered IM or subQ; not for IV administration
    • do not mix with other vaccines in the same syringe
  • Intramuscular
    • infants and small children; preferred injection site is in the mid-lateral aspect of the thigh
    • older children and adults; preferred injection site is in the tissue of the deltoid area
    • preferred dosing interval is at least 8 weeks; minimum dosing interval is 4 weeks
  • Subcutaneous
    • infants and small children; preferred injection site is in the mid-lateral aspect of the thigh
    • older children and adults; preferred injection site is in the tissue of the deltoid area
    • preferred dosing interval is at least 8 weeks; minimum dosing interval is 4 weeks

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause swelling, injection site pain, loss of appetite, vomiting, fatigue, irritability, or fever.
  • Patient should monitor for and report signs/symptoms of a severe allergic reaction, especially within the first 24 h after receiving vaccine.
  • If patient has acute febrile illness before a scheduled dose, advise patient to immediately notify healthcare professional, as vaccination may need to be deferred until patient is well.
  • Instruct patient to call healthcare professional if a treatment is missed, as drug should be given in a fixed series. Emphasize importance of receiving all doses of vaccine in the series.
